title: How the new dynamics have made EastEnders great again
text:
It’s common knowledge that EastEnders has been excelling at so many things lately. From improvements in pacing and narrative techniques, to the strengthening of characters who’s potential had been previously untapped, the BBC One soap is stronger than it’s been in quite some time. In addition to the aforementioned positives, you might have noticed that the show has been experimenting with a multitude of dynamics — and, more specifically, new dynamics — as of late, and if so, you’ll likely agree that this factor has played a huge role in putting the serial drama back at the top of its genre.

Martin Fowler’s (James Bye) recent return, for example, has brought with it the opportunity for yet another great dynamic to be explored, as the character finds himself at the beck-and-call of Ben Mitchell (Max Bowden).

While these two legacy characters have interacted in the past, they’ve had no reason to share scenes in recent years, which is where Kate Oates and Jon Sen come in, as the pair have worked their magic once more to create a great source of conflict which has ensured that these guys have no choice but to share the screen together.

Ben’s got Martin right where he wants him (Picture: BBC)

Fans of Coronation Street and Emmerdale will know that this is something of a Kate Oates speciality, as the acclaimed producer has proven during her time on both of these soaps just how fearless she is when it comes to exploring uncharted territory, and — with Jon at her side — she’s managed it once again on EastEnders.

The thing that sets soaps apart from regular drama series’ is that — in addition to the fact that they’re on all year round —they’re about the residents of a community setting as opposed to being about any one character in particular. Ergo, soaps are ensemble pieces — and history has proven that this is when the genre operates at its best.

EastEnders was undoubtedly once the most community-driven series on the telly, but somewhere along the line it lost a little bit of that sense of community and, as a result, episodes could occasionally feel like a collection of separate narrative threads that — aside from the fact that the action was all taking place on the same square — had no connection to the other concurrently running arcs. As a result, characters had little to no reason to interact with any one not involved in their own storyline.

John Yorke set in motion a change when he began exploring several new dynamics last year — the greatest of which was undoubtedly the relationship between Sharon (Letitia Dean) and Keanu (Danny Walters), which provided both characters — Sharon, in particular — with the best material they’ve had in years.

Sharon and Keanu worked incredibly well (Picture: BBC)

Kate and Jon have since built upon John’s efforts, and — in doing so — they’ve managed to revitalise the show as a whole, and thus fully restore that essence of community.

Let’s face it: EastEnders has always thrived on its wonderful dynamics. Den (Leslie Grantham) and Angie (Anita Dobson), Peggy (Barbara Windsor) and Pat (Pam St Clement), and Mick (Danny Dyer) and Linda (Kellie Bright) are just a few that come to mind.

What’s more, some of the show’s finest over the years have been those between characters that you wouldn’t have necessarily paired up. Dot Cotton (June Brown) and Colin Russell (Michael Cashman), for example, or Jean Slater (Gillian Wright) and Shirley Carter (Linda Henry). For the soap to continually move forward, it’s important that new dynamics such as these ones are born.

It’s a difficult task, for sure. You see, it’s not just a matter of throwing two characters together and seeing if it works — that formula would certainly wear thin rather quickly — but rather, it’s about finding a believable way to bring two characters together — characters who, under any normal circumstances, would have no obvious reason to interact with one another — and building around said reason. In other words, it’s about finding common ground or — in Martin and Ben’s case — a common goal.

With block-storytelling a thing of the past, Kate and Jon were able to do just that, as — because EastEnders is very much an ensemble piece once more thanks to Kate’s efforts — the narrative threads tend to overlap quite frequently, which — not only makes for a much more entertaining show — but also provides more opportunity for new dynamics to be experimented with.

Callum (Tony Clay) and Ben’s relationship is the prime example of how successful this formula’s been. Due to the current interlinking nature of the soap’s storylines, Callum — who was struggling with his sexuality — was able to cross paths with Ben.

This interaction not only allowed for Callum’s internal struggle to come to light in a realistic and believable way, but it also provided him with someone to talk to about said struggle, and Ben — who had previously struggled with his own sexuality — was the perfect person for Callum to confide in. It was then, via this expertly executed storyline, that romance was able to ensue.

The dynamic between Callum and Ben is one of EastEnders’ finest (Picture: BBC)

The same ideology can be applied to Stuart (Ricky Champ) and Rainie’s (Tanya Franks) wonderful relationship. Both characters lived in Walford for near enough a year without ever having reason or opportunity to interact with one another. However, a nifty plot device — i.e. Dot’s inheritance — did the trick, and ultimately resulted in them being forced into each other’s company.

The reason they remained as a duo, however, is down to the fact that — in spite of their efforts to be better people — both have been continually ostracised and pushed out by just about everyone else in their lives, so they ultimately found acceptance in one another.

It’s not just new romantic relationships that have aided in restoring EastEnders’ former glory either, as some of the best dynamics as of late have been those between characters who’ve only interacted a handful of times — which is akin to the interactions you’d see in real-life close-knit communities.

Bobby (Clay Milner Russell), for example, would normally have had no reason to interact with Callum — nor would Lisa (Lucy Benjamin) with Bex (Jasmine Armfield), or Bex with Stuart — but they were brought together because the other person in these equations were able to understand what they were going through at one moment in time and subsequently empathise them.

The same thing can be said about Iqra (Priya Davra) and Keegan (Zack Morris), Habiba (Rukku Nahar) and Honey (Emma Barton), and Kush (Davood Ghadami) and Kat (Jessie Wallace). It’s about common ground.

Of course, the great thing about all of these new dynamics is that, in turn, they’ve provided for plenty of fresh story content. The current Martin and Ben narrative is the perfect example, as the pair were forced into a situation because of the love they have for their families, but they’re ultimately stuck with one another because — much like he always does — Ben spied an opportunity to use said situation to his benefit.

As a result, we’ve got a juicy storyline that could well carry on for several months — which, in a sense, is what soap is all about.

The efforts made by Kate, Jon, John and the entire story team have well and truly paid off, as EastEnders isn’t just in a great place, but rather it’s in one of the best places it’s ever been in — period. The content is new and fresh, and these new dynamics — and, by association, the new storylines — have been instrumental in getting it to this stage.

Yes, much like it was at the beginning — and throughout many of its strongest periods — EastEnders is community-driven once more and, if history has taught us anything, herein lies its strength.

description: From unpredictable romances to newly-formed partnerships, EastEnders feels like a community again — and in therein lies its strength.
